title: 115_s1072
content: The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes per diem payments for care of dependents of homeless veterans and partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes partnerships with public and private entities to fund legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness, ensuring equitable distribution across the United States, including rural communities and tribal lands. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes partnerships with public and private entities to fund legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. Legal services include housing-related assistance like eviction defense, family law support for reunification and child support, and estate planning. Legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness include family law support for reunification, child support, divorce, estate planning, income support, criminal defense for issues related to homelessness, and other services deemed necessary by the Secretary. Consultation with public and private entities is required for partnership development. The Secretary must consult with public and private entities to identify organizations and coordinate outreach relationships for legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. Periodic reports on services provided may be required from entities in partnerships under this section. Expansion of Department of Veterans Affairs authority to provide dental care to homeless veterans. The eligibility criteria for veterans to receive assistance under section 8(o) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 or care in specific settings are outlined in an amendment to section 2062 of title 38, United States Code. The eligibility criteria for veterans to receive assistance or care in specific settings, including community residential care coordinated by the Secretary, and settings funded by the Secretary for grant and per diem providers. The Secretary may disregard breaks in care for which the veteran is not responsible. SEC. 5. Repeal of sunset on authority for referral and counseling services for veterans at risk of homelessness transitioning from certain institutions. Section 2023 of title 38, United States Code, is amended by removing subsection (d) and redesignating subsection (e) as subsection (d). SEC. 6. Extension of authority for financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing. SEC. 6 extends financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing by amending section 2044(e) of title 38, United States Code to allocate $500,000,000 for fiscal year 2017. Additionally, training entities for provision of supportive services are extended through 2017. The Comptroller General of the United States will study Department of Veterans Affairs programs for homeless veterans within 270 days of this Act. The study will assess program effectiveness and review efforts to improve privacy, safety, and security for female veterans. Additionally, the requirement for annual reports on assistance to homeless veterans is repealed. Section 2065 of title 38, United States Code, which mandates annual reports on assistance to homeless veterans, is repealed. The table of sections in chapter 20 of the same title is updated accordingly.
